content:
Examples Validator have unique case that does not appear in any other tests or validators:
-9 -4 2 2 4 9
If solution is based on stack and have and have issues with checks ( positive values are only compared with the top of the stack and never pushed in), it may pass all the tests except this one.

Oof! I only just finished coding it, and was right about to approve as well. This is an original take and good single pass parsing problem that requires keeping track of one variable for validation and another for the result.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool twist on the "matching brackets" problem

It took me a while to understand the first example. It's illustrated well, but the rule could be specified more clearly, for example: "Two integers of opposite sign are used to represent each doll." It also took me a while to understand the second example because there were two sets of 3's and two sets of 1's, and it wasn't clear which doll was encapsulating which. I would suggest something simpler as an example, such as -9 -3 -2 2 3 -5 -2 2 5 9. Then when you refer to the #3 and #5 dolls it's not ambiguous, yet it's also clear that there can legitimately be dolls of the same size within the problem.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I tested my code with the first example, and when passed all the others were ok with no changes. Fun to solve, medium is ok for me.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear description with concrete examples. May need a couple reads. The tests are plenty and quite consistent between public/validator accordingly to my (albeit limited) experimentation. The contribution is original and engaging. 

Le thumbs up.

One caveat I have with this is that you could manage to pass the first test with this faulty logic (expires in one week): https://bpa.st/5PZSM

And then in test #2 you will find yourself alone with a very daunting:

Failure
Found: 1
Expected: 2

In a list of 100 numbers that are between -1 and 3, making isolating the faulty line very difficult.

For the record it was this one that I failed (or maybe some other line before, for all I know). I got lucky that it happened at the end.

1
-9 -7 -3 3 -2 2 7 9

This is not a requirement but if you want to make the puzzle easier to debug I'd suggest to add another round of 11 or so easy tests after the first one, where it is clearer to see the faulty line if that ever happens. Potentially including the line above.

I know now what my code was lacking, and while I don't think it is strictly necessary, I would write in "bold" the word solid in both:
> The size #1 doll is a solid wood
> count how many solid dolls are in the set.
since this is personally the piece of information that got away from me. This again, of course, is also up to preference.

And I agree with the Medium difficulty. Nice puzzle.

Goal
* Please fix the typo: craftman => craftsman.

* Please add "of" after "thousands".

Output
* Please format "-1" as a {{constant}}.

Difficulty
* I suggest to set the difficulty to Medium.

Cases
* I haven't checked in detail how similar the error cases in the tests are to those in the validators. Please make sure they should be similar, despite your error detection reminder in the statement, because validators should "validate the same kind of scenario" (quoted from the contribution guidelines) as the tests. In other words, the players should be able to write a code to cover all the possible errors based on the visible tests alone.

Thanks.
Not sure this puzzle is Easy or Medium level. Let me know if you feel a change of category is suitable. Thanks.

Thanks your effort to review. Problems fixed.
All invalid cases should have been covered by the given examples.

One shorter set of test cases is added. Hope that it covers most nesting possibilities and at the same time is easy enough to count line by line.

I often have to handle massive I/O data. To compare my output to a sample output, I usually use a diff tool and a few copy and paste keystrokes. It never fails me.

Thanks your comments and suggestions. They are valid. I applied them by updating some wordings and added graphical illustrations to the harder example to visually explain how the numbers are encapsulated.
A few test cases are added to demonstrate this one.

I mean if I really wanted to check the faulty lines I probably would have used this repo to solve it locally which has a better error messaging: https://github.com/Andriamanitra/coctus

The issue is not that I don't know how to do it, but that the average person solving this probably won't.

I haven't fixed my code yet nor run the new test. I will let you know once I do.

Update.

I solved it, it was just a couple lines.

Another caveat. I can pass all validators (but not one public test: Advanced Doll Sets) by commenting two lines of logic (24-25). https://bpa.st/IG7QW

I would suggest to copy this line

-0 0

from Advanced Doll Sets to its corresponding validator. It is enough an edge case that I think the copying is deserved.

Edit: simplified the code.

Updated by your suggestions.
Thanks your effort in trying out everything.

I am a bit scared about the just 0 line you added in the validator. It does not affect my code but I could see someone failing because of it not being tested publicly anywhere.

The easy solution is to just add it at the start of the corresponding test ofc.

Other than that it looks good to me.

Done.
Besides that, I also updated a line (line 1) in the "Complicated Nesting" set. I guess your code should have no problem passing it.

I see, that's evil but it is a good test :D

I am going to approve it. I didn't reread the statement for typos, I hope someone else is able to do it.
